awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Fostering Collaborative Computer Science Learning with Intelligent Virtual Companions for Upper Elementary Students
awd_abstract_narration:
There is growing recognition that children can, and should, learn computer science. One of the central tenets of computer science is that it is a collaborative discipline, yet children do not start out with an intrinsic ability to collaborate. The project will provide the opportunity for upper elementary students to learn computer science and build strong collaboration practices. Leveraging the promise of virtual learning companions, the project will address three thrusts. First, the project will collect datasets of collaborative learning for computer science in diverse upper elementary school classrooms. Second, the project will design, develop, and iteratively refine its intelligent virtual learning companions, which support dyads of students in a scaffolded computer science learning environment with an interactive online coding tool. Third, the project will generate research findings and evidence about how children collaborate in computer science learning, and how best to support their collaboration with intelligent virtual learning companions. There will be three families of deliverables: learning activities and professional development, an intelligent learning environment with virtual learning companions, and research evidence that furthers the state of scholarship and practice surrounding the collaborative learning of computer science. The project will situate itself in highly diverse elementary schools in two states, Durham County, North Carolina and Alachua County, Florida. This project is supported by the Discovery Research PreK-12 program, which funds research and development of STEM innovations and approaches. 

The project addresses the research question, "How can we support upper elementary-school students in computer science learning and collaboration using intelligent virtual learning companions?" The initial dataset will provide a ground-truth measure of students' collaboration approaches to classroom computer science learning tasks through instrumenting computer labs in elementary schools for collecting dialogue and problem-solving activity. The project will collect triangulating qualitative data to better understand impactful classroom dynamics around dyadic learning of computer science. The technical innovation of the project is the way in which student dyads are supported: each pair of children within the elementary school classroom will interact with a dyad of state of-the-art intelligent virtual learning companions. These companions will enhance the classroom experience by adapting in real time to the students' patterns of collaboration and problem solving to provide tailored support specifically for that pair of students. The virtual learning companions will model crucial dimensions of healthy collaboration through their dialogue with one another, including self-explanation, question generation, attributing challenges to the task and not to deficits in each other, and establishing common ground through uptake of ideas. The project will compare outcomes of computer science learning as measured in two ways: individual pre-test to post-test, and quality of collaboratively produced solutions. The project team will measure collaborative practices through dialogue analysis for the target collaboration strategies, as well as interest and self-efficacy for computer science. The project will utilize a multilevel model design to study the effect of the virtual learning companions on student outcomes. Using speech, dialogue transcripts, code artifact analysis, and multimodal analysis of gesture and facial expression, the team will conduct sequential analyses that identify the virtual learning companion interactions that are particularly beneficial for students, and focus our development efforts on expanding and refining those interactions. They will also identify the affordances that students did not engage with and determine whether to eliminate or re-cast them. The analytics of collaborative process data will once again be augmented with qualitative classroom data from field notes, focus groups, and semi-structured interviews with students and teachers. The themes that emerge will guide subsequent refinement of the environment and learning activities.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of the FLECKS project was to develop a transformative learning experience for upper elementary students to learn computer science as they build collaboration skills. This project sought to afford students the opportunity to simultaneously learn computer science and build collaborative skills through the development of virtual learning companions who will scaffold and support students as they interact with the FLECKS learning environment. The project made significant contributions in the following areas:

 

1) Working directly with youth, we co-designed, developed, and iteratively refined a pair of virtual agents who can represent good collaborative practices while portraying peer personas that students found authentic, agreeable, and knowledgeable. Through the process of iteratively developing these agents, we have obtained numerous design implications which are valuable to the CS education community in guiding the design of virtual agents for upper elementary students. We have also developed 27 unique dialogues for these agents that model specific collaboration skills, such as listening to one’s partner, or that provide task-specific support, to help prevent students from becoming stuck and disengaged. This format, of paired peer agents modeling good collaborative practices, is novel to the field. We used a Wizard of Oz paradigm (controlled by a trained human) to simulate the intelligent behavior of the agents using these collaboratively designed dialogues. Results showed that students had more positive responses to the agents’ interventions, and took up their suggestions, under particular design conditions that generated readily actionable design implications for further iterations.

 

2) We developed the FLECKS collaborative coding platform for upper elementary students. This platform is built upon the NetsBlox block-based coding language, which allows students to construct programs using coding elements represented as blocks on a graphical interface, creating a “scene” on a visual “stage” as code output. The FLECKS platform is web-based. It allows teachers to load in customized coding tasks and create student accounts with unique logins; researchers can collect fine-grained interaction logs; and students are able to log in, view instructions, and work on each assigned coding task. It can be used with or without the virtual agents, which are poised to be integrated with a fully implemented intelligent support model. 

 

3) Leveraging the rich dataset collected throughout the development and testing process, the project investigated collaborative behaviors of upper elementary student coders and the impact of different programming paradigms and system designs on this behavior. We have compared multiple pair programming paradigms, such as same computer versus separate computers, and analyzed the challenges and affordances posed by each. We modeled students’ responses to simulated agent interventions using multimodal data, identifying patterns in suggestion uptake that drove further research. The project has modeled students’ collaborative dialogue to identify typical states and patterns (series of states) in that dialogue that are associated with both productive collaboration and unproductive. A number of other modeling studies have been undertaken in this vein, yielding diverse insights into how collaboration unfolds and the factors that impact it. Finally, this dataset has also allowed us to investigate the unique data processing challenges that face adaptive systems in classroom contexts as they attempt to detect speakers and use data to identify key states for intervention.

 

4) We have disseminated research findings from the FLECKS project with scholars and practitioners through numerous publications, presentations, and workshops. To date the findings of the project have been reported in 5 journal articles, 17 conference papers, 1 book chapter, and 1 poster. Findings from this set of published work will guide future research and development on engaging, effective curricular strategies for computer science education.
